title: Ticket #3723: Frequent shadow crashes on CMS machine at CERN
description:
Igor Sfiligoi reports that he's seeing frequent shadow crashes (about 12 a day) on machine vocms83.cern.ch. Examination of the logs and core files indicates the crashes are due to the passwd_cache class being called recursively inside of _set_priv() due to a getpwnam() call failing. passwd_cache isn't designed to be called this way, and is probably corrupting memory as a result.

The getpwnam() failures claim that the user doesn't exist, though we know the user existed when the job was submitted and when the shadow was born. Almost all of the failures occur at 17:44 local time each day. This suggests that there is a regular, short-lived outage of the ldap service each day.

Here is the sequence of events shown by the stack trace quoted below:

  • Shadow wants to write a job usage update log event
  • Log event code calls _set_priv() to switch effective uid/gid to the job user
  • _set_priv() calls into passwd_cache to lookup and set supplemental groups for the user
  • passwd_cache decides cached information about the user and their groups is stale, starts updating cache entry with new information
  • passwd_cache calls getpwnam(), which returns failure
  • passwd_cache calls dprintf() to log failure
  • dprintf() calls _set_priv() to switch effective uid/gid to condor
  • dprintf() writes failure to log
  • dprintf() calls _set_priv() to restore previous effecive uid/gid, which is the user
  • _set_priv() calls into passwd_cache to lookup and set supplemental groups for the user
  • passwd_cache starts to update cache with new information about user and supplemental groups
  • BOOM!

_set_priv() takes an argument indicating when it shouldn't call dprintf(), used when dprintf() calls _set_priv(). This avoids a crash-inducing recursion. The passwd_cache object doesn't have a similar flag, so when _set_priv() calls into passwd_cache, it has no way to tell passwd_cache not to call dprintf(). There's a similar problem when _set_priv() is called during process creation on unix, between the fork()/clone() and exec() in the child process. _set_priv() has to be careful about any modifications to memory. passwd_cache won't respect that restriction.

Condor version: 

$CondorVersion: 7.8.8 Mar 20 2013 BuildID: 110288 $
$CondorPlatform: x86_rhap_5.8 $

An additional annoyance was noticed while examining the shadow logs. In this Condor installation, the Condor user is "_condor", rather than the usual "condor". There is no "condor" user on the system. The CONDOR_IDS variable is set to indicate the "_condor" user. But every time a shadow starts up, it makes two calls to getpwnam() for the user "condor", which fail. Given the presence of the CONDOR_IDS variable, why is the shadow looking for the "condor" user? This puts more load on the ldap server and clutters the logs for no purpose.

The default expiration time for entries in passwd_cache is 5 minutes. This seems overly short. Changes to existing user accounts should be an infrequent event. Lengthening the default cache expiration to several hours should cut down on calls to the ldap server without much trouble due to stale information.

Also, when a cache entry becomes stale, if new calls to getpwnam() and friends fail, we should keep and use the old cache entry for a short period longer. This would allow Condor to better handle short-lived ldap outages.

Proposed remedies:

  • _set_priv() should never call into the passwd_cache object. When init_user_ids() or set_file_owner_ids() is called, supplemental group information should be copied for _set_priv()'s private use. [DONE]
  • _set_priv() and its help functions should be audited to ensure they don't call dprintf() or modify memory when the dologging parameter says they shouldn't. [DONE]
  • In passwd_cache, when a cache entry is stale, if getpwnam() or friends fail, keep and use the old cache entry for a limited period of time.
  • When CONDOR_IDS is set, don't try to lookup the "condor" user in passwd_cache at daemon startup. [DONE]
  • Lengthen the default passwd_cache entry lifetime from 5 minutes to 20 hours. This is config param PASSWD_CACHE_REFRESH. [DONE]
